APIs are our secret sauce so this website is specifically designed to illustrate the unique selling points of our Qlik Sense APIs.
Our goal is to illustrate the power of Qlik Sense APIs in language that can be easily understood by non-technical business users or decision-makers via our step-by-step walk-through.
Take the audience on a journey highlighting key aspects of Qlik Sense, the APIs and the value of Qlik.  This journey culminates in an easy to use demonstration website which includes:
- Multi-tenant API solution for both Qlik Sense Hub and QMC. (*Loop and reduce*)
- API, the generated REST API request and responses
- Facilitate different levels of self service

<q>Create charts on the fly using the Vizualization API</q>
If you don't want to create charts up front, you can create them on the fly using javascript or visual web components.

```
app.visualization.create('barchart',["Case Owner Group","=Avg([Case Duration Time])"],
 {"title":"On the fly barchart"}
```
[Visuals web components](https://help.qlik.com/en-US/sense-developer/3.1/Subsystems/APIs/Content/QlikVisual/qlik-visual.htm). Use Sense HTML Tags in a declarative manner

```
<qlik-visual appid="Helpdesk Management.qvf"     
type="barchart"     cols='["Case Owner Group","=Avg([Case Duration Time])"]'     
options='{"title":"On the fly barchart"}'></qlik-visual>
```

Level 2: Qlik Sense security as part of a governance framework
Level 3:
Key risks to mitigate for a typical organization
- Unreliable reporting
- Multiple version of the truth
- User requirements are not met
- Performance issues
- Information is disclosed to unauthorized persons

Key questions to ask in order to segregate duties between users:
- where are the users stored?
- can you re-use exsting (AD) groups outside of Qlik?
- or do you need some option to create and assign groups/roles to users in Qlik Sense?

Level 2: Typical questions to ask to get started...
Level 3:
- User - how does he login?
- Which device does he use? 
- Where is he located? Internal in domain/office - external
- Where are the servers? And how do they authenticate?
- Which authenticated method to use for Qlik Sense?  AD, header, SAML, ticket?
- Where can you get the group membership from? (for authorization purposes)

Level 2: Introduction to self service: a consumer

Level 3: Authorize stream only, give access to all apps inside
Use the group of the ticket in the rule

App_*, App.Object_*
```
(resource.stream.HasPrivilege("read")) or (resource.resourcetype = "App.Object" and resource.published ="true" and resource.app.HasPrivilege("read"))
```

Level 2: Introduction to self service: a contributor

Level 3: A user with group contributor is allowed to create sheets in existing apps, but no app creation

Level 2: Introduction to self service: a developer

Level 3: A user with group developer is allowed to create apps, sheets and load data. And the owner of a resource should be able to do Update and Delete actions if the resource is not published to a stream

```
 user.environment.group = "Developer" and ((resource.owner = user and resource.stream.Empty()) or (resource.app.HasPrivilege("read") and resource.published ="false" ))
```

Level 2: Introduction to self service: a customer specific admin

Level 3: Administrators are only allowed to maintain the apps and app.object in the QMC

What can you do with the QRS API?
- Basically everything you can do in the Qlik Sense Management Console (QMC)
- copy/delete apps and streams
- reload apps
- get and update system rules
- get (extract) and update settings

Level 2: How to create the source code?
How to create the source code?

Level 3: All services in the Qlik Sense deployment authenticate their communication using an SSL certificate.

The same certificate can also be used to authenticate with the Qlik Sense Repository Service (QRS) and Proxy (QPS) API. When authenticating using this method, the communication is made directly against the QRS/QPS.
If APIs are to be accessed from a remote server, client certificates need to be exported from the Qlik Management Console (QMC) and installed on the calling server.
All requests must carry administrator level permissions
Always start to make the solution as simple as possible
Try to open the app directly (hub)
Press F12- console to see if you have errors
Try to close your browser an  re-open
Try to open the link in your browser and see the result
Do you see the source code? (ok)

- get (extract) and update settings like tasks, licences, security, users ....

Level 2: What can you do with the QRS REST API?

Level 3: Most Qlik Sense APIs are delivered as a REpresentational State Transfer (REST) web service that contains a number of endpoints (also referred to as paths) that are used to execute various functions.
To communicate with these endpoints, HTTP calls that contain GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE requests are made.

How to authenticate with the server certificate?
Level 3:
To authenticate using this method:
- The location where the authentication request originates must have a copy of the client SSL certificate.
- If you plan to access the APIs from a remote server, you must export client certificates from the Qlik Management Console (QMC) and install them on the calling server.

Level 2: How to authenticate with the server certificate?
How to authenticate with a Windows user account
Level 3: You must send requests via the proxy server URL

You can use a custom HTTP header to authenticate requests. This header contains the
-  user name to be presented to the Qlik Sense Repository Service (QRS) API. 
- In this case, you must send requests via the proxy server URL.

Level 2: Example API request with header authentication
Example API request with header authentication
Example API request with header authentication
Example API request with header authentication

Level 3: A common vulnerability in web clients is cross-site request forgery, which lets an attacker impersonate a user when accessing a system. To protect against this vulnerability, calls to the Qlik Sense Repository Service (QRS) API must include the following:

To protect you have to use a header and parameter:
- Xrfkey parameter: Must equal 16 arbitrary characters. 
- x-Qlik-Xrfkey: Custom HTTP header. The format is as follows:
Example API call that returns all server node configurations in the repository database:

```
https://localhost:4242/qrs/servernodeconfiguration/full?Xrfkey= abcdefghijklmnop HTTP/1.1
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
X-Qlik-User: UserDirectory=INTERNAL; UserId=sa_repository
Accept-Charset: utf-8; q=0.9, us-ascii;q=0.1, iso-8859-1
Accept: text/xml; q=0.1, application/json; q=0.2
X-Qlik-Xrfkey: abcdefghijklmnop
Host: localhost:4242
Connection: Keep-Alive
User-Agent: Apache-HttpClient/4.1.1 (java 1.5)
```
*Basically you can do all the things you normally do in the QMC*

What can you do with the Engine API?

Basically everything you can do when you open an app in the hub.
- Get list of streams and apps
- Open an app
- Get the layout (sheets and charts)
- Insert script
- Reload the app
- Copy an app

This tool lets you see 
- which functionality is available
- what are the requests and responses

Server responds
``` 
{
 "jsonrpc": "2.0",
 "id": 3,
 "result": {
  "qDocList": [
   {
    "qDocName": "Cloudy Petrol - My first template",
    "qConnectedUsers": 0,
    "qFileTime": 0,
    "qFileSize": 0,
    "qDocId": "435bbe2a-3d78-425e-9e2c-c48cae8f60f3",
    "qMeta": {
     "modifiedDate": "2016-10-11T17:27:03.820Z",
     "published": false,
     "publishTime": "1753-01-01T00:00:00.000Z",
```
In this example we will get a "table" of data out of Qlik Sense using the Engine API
The Engine API is a websocket based protocol (JSON RPC)
Because our website is written in Javanscript. We use a javascript library Enigma.js to "talk to the Qlik Sense Eninge API
